properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwest winds gusting to 90 km/h are expected beginning late tonight through Tuesday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain coming to an end and strong winds developing this afternoon. Rain early this morning will continue through the day today before coming to an end late this afternoon or early this evening. Local rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are expected by the time the rain comes to an end. Strong westerly winds are also forecast to develop this afternoon into this evening. Wind gusts up to 60 or 70 km/h will be possible. These strong winds will ease tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm, possibly higher near the Fundy coast. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h, possibly higher along the Fundy coast. Locations: western to central New Brunswick. Time span: this afternoon until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Rain will begin near noon today over western New Brunswick, then spread across the province this afternoon. The rain is expected to become heavy at times this evening before ending early Tuesday morning. Strong southerly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rainfall, resulting in rapid snowmelt. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-14T00:30:08-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain tonight and Monday and strong winds Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Rain is forecast to begin tonight north of Lake Ontario and will expand into Eastern Ontario by Monday morning. Local rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are expected. The rain will taper off from west to east Monday. Strong westerly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible. These strong winds will ease Monday night. These winds and rain are associated with a strong low pressure system that is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T17:43:37-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from Colorado will approach James Bay early in the week. Snow will begin Monday afternoon and the storm will then intensify during the evening. A total of 15 to 20 centimetres of snow, strong winds and significant blowing snow giving near-zero visibilities are expected. Conditions will improve on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T18:39:02-00:00

properties.Summary:

Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible with the strongest winds expected along the shorelines of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie. The winds will ease tonight. There is the potential for scattered power outages due to the strong winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:

Wind gusts up to 100 km/h will be possible with the strongest winds expected along the shorelines of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie. These strong winds will ease Monday night. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today with the highest amounts near and east of Marathon and lower amounts near Terrace Bay and Schreiber. Snow has begun over the area and is expected to become heavy this morning. Northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h are also expected today resulting in areas of blowing snow. The heavy snow and local blowing snow will taper to flurries tonight. Storm total snowfall amounts near 20 cm are expected over eastern sections near or east of Marathon with lesser amounts further west toward Terrace Bay and Schreiber. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Major winter storm today into tonight. A strong low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario today bringing heavy snow and blowing snow to the area. Snow has already begun early this morning near Kapuskasing. It will continue to spread northeastward to reach Moosonee late this morning and Fort Albany by noon. Northerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h are also forecast with this storm resulting in widespread blowing snow. The snow and blowing snow will continue into tonight before tapering to flurries on Tuesday. Total snowfall amounts in the 30 to 50 cm range are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-14T01:14:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-13T09:15:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1692310089.2020
Area: Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow across many areas today. Mainly rain with the risk of freezing rain for other areas. Snow and rain will continue over the area today. A narrow zone of freezing rain has also developed near a frontal boundary. This boundary extends from near Timmins to near Chapleau to Lake Superior Park this morning but will continue to drift northward today. By this evening any freezing rain associated with this boundary will come to an end or transition back to snow. The snow will taper to flurries tonight. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 50 km are also forecast to develop later today resulting in local blowing snow. Significant snowfall amounts in the 25 to 40 cm range are expected by the time the snow comes to and end. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-14T01:15:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-13T09:16:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1832814225.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly at 100 km/h. Locations: west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: early Tuesday morning until near noon. Remarks: Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Trout River Bay, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow today, especially east of Longlac. A strong low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario today bringing heavy snow to the area. Snow has already begun and will become heavy today. Northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h will also result in local blowing snow today and tonight. This snow and blowing snow will continue into this evening before tapering to flurries tonight. Storm total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected in areas east of Longlac. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-14T01:17:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-13T09:18:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3606048334.2020
Area: Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Major winter storm continues today. Heavy snow will continue today as a strong low pressure system tracks across Northeastern Ontario. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will also cause widespread blowing snow. This snow and blowing snow will taper to flurries tonight. Total snowfall amounts in the 30 to 50 cm range are expected by the time the snow comes to an end. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-14T01:13:21-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Rainfall amounts between 30 and 40 millimetres are expected. The rain will be heavier overnight tonight. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds this afternoon into this evening. Strong west to southwesterly winds are forecast to develop this afternoon into this evening. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible. The strong winds will ease tonight. Scattered power outages will be possible due to these strong winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Blizzard conditions have developed in the Naujaat area and are expected to persist today, tonight and Monday with gradual improvement occurring Monday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain near Foleyet transitioning to rain this morning. Mainly rain farther south, including in Gogama. Rain will continue over most areas today with freezing rain near Foleyet early this morning transitioning to rain later this morning. The rain will then change back to flurries or periods of snow late this afternoon. Storm total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible near Foleyet. Poor travel conditions are expected in areas that receive significant snow and freezing rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
